name: K2-80
scenarioDescription:
The K2-80 Exoplanetary System

K2-80 is a star with 0.9 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.87 times its radius. It is located 658.70 light years away from the solar system.

K2-80 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

K2-80 b

K2-80 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 19.09 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-80.

The mass of K2-80 b is 5.12 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-80 b is 2.01 that of Earth. At 5.12 Earth masses, K2-80 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

K2-80 c

K2-80 c was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.61 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-80.

The mass of K2-80 c is 2.42 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-80 c is 1.47 that of Earth. At 2.42 Earth masses, K2-80 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-80, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by K2.
